case_vignette:
A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg, and pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is negative. An electrocardiogram shows absent p-waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis? 
Original text:
A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg, and pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is negative. An electrocardiogram shows absent p-waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I am currently unconscious and have multiple bruises over my chest, a cut on my abdomen and one on my scalp.
Are you currently in an environment where you can receive immediate medical attention, such as a hospital?
Yes, I was brought to the emergency department.
Do you remember if the onset of unconsciousness was sudden after a particular event such as an accident?
Yes, I became unconscious right after being involved in a motor vehicle collision.
Did you experience any chest pain or difficulty breathing before losing consciousness?
I'm not aware of having chest pain or difficulty breathing before losing consciousness.
Were there any findings or observations noted by emergency responders or hospital staff upon your arrival at the hospital?
Yes, upon arrival, they noted that my blood pressure was very low, my pulse was very fast and irregular, I had multiple bruises over my chest, and cuts on my abdomen and scalp.
Based on the symptoms and the situation described, have any imaging tests like an X-ray or ultrasound been performed on your chest or abdomen?
Yes, a focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) was performed, which was negative.
Has an echocardiogram been performed to check for issues related to the structure and function of your heart?
No, an echocardiogram has not been mentioned; only an electrocardiogram was performed which showed absent p-waves.
Was there any prediction of fluid or blood in the pericardial space based on the imaging and physical findings?
No, there was no prediction of fluid or blood in the pericardial space based on the imaging and physical findings.
Final Diagnosis: Commotio Cordis

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient was brought to the emergency department unconscious and bearing multiple bruises over their chest, along with cuts on their abdomen and scalp. The unconsciousness ensued immediately after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was not aware of experiencing chest pain or difficulty breathing prior to losing consciousness. Upon arrival, medical personnel observed that the patient had very low blood pressure, a fast and irregular pulse, alongside the aforementioned bruises and cuts. A Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) was conducted and returned negative results. No echocardiogram was mentioned; however, an electrocardiogram was performed which indicated absent P-waves. No fluid or blood was predicted in the pericardial space based on imaging and physical findings.
